population_specificity: Infant formula products (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether skin autofluorescence (SAF) levels, indicating Advanced Glycation End Products, could predict major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) in heart failure patients undergoing cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: Higher SAF levels were independently associated with increased MACE risk, including all-cause mortality and HF hospitalization, after adjusting for confounding factors. Kaplan-Meier analysis showed a significantly higher incidence of MACE in the high SAF group.
population_specificity: 204 consecutive heart failure patients who underwent cardiac rehabilitation at a university hospital.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to explore the role of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGE) and their receptors in the context of COPD, particularly in disease progression and mortality.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding the effects of Advanced Glycation End Products, only mentioning their relevance in COPD.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic changes induced by a low AGE diet in non-diabetic patients undergoing peritoneal dialysis.
results_summary: The low AGE diet significantly altered circulating metabolomes (166 molecules) and lipidomes (91 lipids), targeting sphingolipid, ether-lipids, and glycerophospholipid metabolism, and replicated some plasma characteristics of healthy aging.
population_specificity: 20 non-diabetic patients undergoing peritoneal dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hishi extract reduces Advanced Glycation End Products (AGE) and improves live birth rates in older assisted reproductive technology (ART) patients.
results_summary: Hishi extract significantly decreased AGE levels in serum and follicular fluid, improved oocyte developmental potential and endometrial receptivity, and increased cumulative live birth rates (47% vs. 16% in controls).
population_specificity: Older ART patients (38-42 years old) without diabetes, uterine anomalies, or exhausted ovarian reserve.
study_duration: Until late pregnancy or treatment failure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of physical activity on sRAGEs and its ligands S100A8/A9 in healthy young individuals.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in S100A8/A9 levels after the training period, suggesting an anti-inflammatory effect of exercise. Primary rodent ASMCs were analyzed for responsiveness to S100A8/A9 and sRAGEs, but detailed results are not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Young Greek army recruits (169 completed the study out of 332 volunteers).
study_duration: Standard basic training period (duration not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of HMGA1, particularly its extracellular interaction with RAGE (receptor for advanced glycation end products), in driving tumor progression in cancers, including triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).
results_summary: The study found that HMGA1 is secreted from TNBC cell lines and signals through RAGE to promote tumor invasion and metastatic progression. Primary TNBC tumor studies also suggest HMGA1 secretion is associated with distant metastasis.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cell lines and primary TNBC tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review skin disorders in pediatric patients with type 1 diabetes and explore the potential of non-invasive evaluation of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) for assessing diabetes-related complications.
results_summary: The study found that skin disorders, including insulin-induced lipodystrophies and allergic contact dermatitis, are common in pediatric type 1 diabetes patients. Non-invasive measurement of skin AGEs may help assess the risk of chronic diabetes complications early.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with type 1 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an equol-containing supplement on metabolism, aging-related biomarkers, and climacteric symptoms, with a focus on Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that equol supplementation significantly improved climacteric symptoms but did not show broad benefits for metabolic and aging-related biomarkers. However, in certain populations (equol producers), there was significant improvement in skin autofluorescence (a measure of AGEs) and visceral fat area.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal Japanese women (mean age: 56±5.37 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of advanced glycation end products (AGEs) in the pathophysiology of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and explore potential mechanisms involving SIRT1.
results_summary: The study found that altered AGE deposition is common in all PCOS phenotypes and suggested that anti-AGE interventions could help counteract PCOS and its fertility effects. The role of SIRT1 in mitigating glycation injury in oocytes and ovaries was also highlighted.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age with PCOS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the association between dietary advanced glycation end products (AGEs) and chronic inflammation, comparing them with other dietary patterns and exploring their pathophysiological mechanisms.
results_summary: The study suggests that dietary AGEs are linked to inflammation and oxidative stress, potentially contributing to chronic diseases. It highlights the importance of exogenous AGEs from food, comparing their effects to other dietary patterns like Mediterranean and DASH diets.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of experimental models, epidemiologic data, and small clinical trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of the glyoxalase system in detoxifying advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) and explore its potential as a therapeutic target for age-related diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights the glyoxalase system, particularly glyoxalase 1 (GLO1), as a key mechanism for detoxifying AGEs, with tissue-dependent regulation. It suggests modulating this system could delay age-related diseases and identifies nutritional compounds that may influence it.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on tissue-dependent mechanisms, with emphasis on the eye retina).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the reduction of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) through skin autofluorescence (SAF) measurement during treatment with adalimumab in psoriatic patients.
results_summary: The study found that AGEs, along with ESR, PASI, and VAS for pain, decreased over the 24-week treatment period with adalimumab, suggesting a potential benefit in reducing AGE accumulation.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severe chronic plaque psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biohumoral and metabolic effects of a nutraceutical formulation (BHC) containing berberine, hesperidin, and chromium picolinate as an add-on therapy in T2D patients with suboptimal glycemic control on metformin.
results_summary: After 12 weeks, the group receiving metformin plus BHC showed significant improvements in glucose profile, including reductions in HbA1c and fasting blood glucose (FBG decreased from 145 ± 20 mg/dL to 128 ± 23 mg/dL).
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) patients with suboptimal glycemic compensation receiving metformin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of yacon flour consumption combined with an energy-restricted diet on glycation markers (AGEs and sRAGE) and their associations with obesity-related factors in adults with excess body weight.
results_summary: The study found that consuming 25 g of yacon flour with an energy-restricted diet did not increase glycation markers (AGEs and early glycation products). Changes in glycation markers were positively associated with changes in body fat, insulin, and insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Adults with excess body weight (n=26).
effective_dosage: 25 g of yacon flour daily (containing 8.7 g of fructooligosaccharides).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-glycation and anti-oxidative properties of phloroglucinol in vitro, comparing it to other known agents.
results_summary: Phloroglucinol demonstrated the strongest and broadest protective effects against protein glycation, glycoxidation, and oxidative damage in both an albumin glycation/oxidation model and HepG2 cells under high glucose conditions, outperforming other tested agents.
population_specificity: In vitro models (albumin glycation/oxidation and HepG2 cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) in diabetic myocardial fibrosis and identify potential therapeutic targets to attenuate fibrosis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that AGEs are implicated in diabetic fibrosis, but the molecular mechanisms linking metabolic perturbations to fibrogenic activation remain poorly understood. No specific results on AGEs' effects are detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update knowledge on the molecular mechanisms of AGEs in diabetes complications and evaluate newer measurement techniques like SAF for assessing risk.
results_summary: The study highlights AGEs' role in cellular stress and proinflammatory mechanisms linked to diabetes complications and identifies SAF as a promising noninvasive tool for risk assessment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on diabetes complications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility of reducing dietary AGEs on cognition and cerebral blood flow in older adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Higher AGEs were reversely associated with cognitive functioning at baseline. The intervention improved global cognition, especially in participants with mild cognitive impairment, but did not affect cerebral blood flow despite lowering AGEs exposure.
population_specificity: Older adults with type 2 diabetes, including those with mild cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate differences in biomarkers, including soluble receptor for advanced glycation end-products (sRAGE), among severe COVID-19 patients treated with or without dexamethasone.
results_summary: Severe COVID-19 patients had elevated sRAGE levels, indicating inflammation. Dexamethasone use was associated with significant decreases in sRAGE and other endothelial injury biomarkers, suggesting potential benefits in reducing inflammation and endothelial damage without delaying viral clearance.
population_specificity: 31 patients with severe COVID-19 (6 on mechanical ventilation, 11 on high-flow nasal cannula, 15 on supplemental oxygen) and 13 controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate serum levels of sRAGE, AGEs, and AOPPs in euthyroid children with Hashimoto's thyroiditis (HT) and investigate their relationships with thyroid function parameters.
results_summary: sRAGE levels were significantly lower in HT patients compared to controls, while no differences were found in AGEs or AOPPs. The findings suggest autoimmunity may reduce sRAGE independently of thyroid function alterations.
population_specificity: Euthyroid pediatric patients with newly diagnosed Hashimoto's thyroiditis (19 cases) and age-, sex-, and BMI-matched healthy controls (16 individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review how advanced glycation end products (AGEs) accumulate in bone tissue and negatively impact bone health and structural integrity in individuals with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The study found that AGE accumulation in bone reduces fracture resistance and impairs bone remodeling and energy absorption, though larger clinical studies are needed to confirm these effects and explore potential interventions. Hyperglycemia drives systemic AGE formation, which subsequently accumulates in bone tissue.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of RAGE and its ligands, including Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs), in disease pathways and potential therapeutic inhibition strategies.
results_summary: The study found that RAGE and its ligands activate multiple signaling pathways linked to diseases like diabetes, inflammation, neurodegeneration, and cancer, suggesting targeted inhibition could be a viable treatment approach.
population_specificity: Not specified (general disease mechanisms discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) as diagnostic biomarkers in clinical practice and review recent advancements in their quantification methods.
results_summary: The study found that while new AGEs and analytical methods (e.g., mass spectrometry) are emerging, there is no consensus on a gold standard for measurement. Skin autofluorescence is increasingly used but lacks specificity, and carboxymethyllysine remains the most measured AGE in biological fluids. Standardization challenges hinder clinical implementation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general clinical research context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanistic roles of carbonyl compounds and advanced glycation end products (AGEs) in diabetes complications and evaluate potential therapeutic strategies to mitigate their harmful effects.
results_summary: The study found that carbonyl stress and AGEs contribute to atherosclerosis, insulin resistance, thrombogenicity, and endothelial dysfunction in diabetes. It highlighted the potential of antiglycation agents, including clinically used drugs and plant extracts, to alleviate these effects, though further clinical trials are needed.
population_specificity: Animal and cell culture models of diabetes, as well as patients with diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the role of neurodegeneration in diabetic retinopathy and review the molecular basis, diagnostic features, and therapeutic interventions related to Advanced Glycation End Products.
results_summary: The study discusses how Advanced Glycation End Products amplify neurodegeneration processes in diabetic retinopathy, including oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis, but does not provide specific efficacy results.
population_specificity: Individuals with diabetic retinopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of RAGE in severe COVID-19 and its potential as a therapeutic target for SARS-CoV-2 infections.
results_summary: The study found that hyperactivation of RAGE contributes to inflammation and oxidative stress in severe COVID-19 comorbidities and is linked to the deleterious effects of the renin-angiotensin system, suggesting RAGE as a key player in severe COVID-19 and a potential therapeutic target.
population_specificity: Severe COVID-19 patients and those with related comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) as key regulators in UV-induced skin photoaging and explore dietary components' potential to mitigate these effects.
results_summary: The abstract identifies AGEs as one of the key regulators driving photoaging-associated skin changes but does not provide specific results on AGEs' direct effects. It highlights that dietary components may alleviate photoaging by maintaining skin moisture, regulating extracellular matrix synthesis/degradation, and providing antioxidant benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research, including animal models and clinical trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of S100/calgranulins in atherosclerosis and explore their potential as therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study found that S100A8, S100A9, and S100A12 proteins play a key role in atherosclerosis pathogenesis and could be targeted by small molecules to treat inflammatory diseases, though further research is needed to clarify their molecular mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of AGEs/RAGE-mediated oxidative stress and inflammation in diabetic kidney disease (DKD) and ageing kidney, and to assess potential intervention strategies targeting this pathway.
results_summary: The study found that AGEs accumulation and RAGE activation contribute to oxidative stress and inflammation in DKD and ageing kidney, suggesting that targeting this pathway could be a promising therapeutic approach.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic kidney disease and ageing kidney conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of RAGE axis activation and its interaction with the renin-angiotensin system in the inflammatory response to SARS-CoV-2 infection in IBD patients.
results_summary: The study found that IBD patients do not have an increased risk of severe SARS-CoV-2 infection, likely due to high expression of soluble RAGE and ACE2, which dampen inflammatory responses by acting as decoys and attenuating RAGE axis activation.
population_specificity: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the detrimental effects of advanced glycation end products (AGEs) on bone quality and fracture risk in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: AGEs form nonenzymatic crosslinks in bone collagen, stiffening and embrittling bone, reducing its fracture resistance. Clinical measurement of AGEs is indirect and fails to distinguish specific AGE properties.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between airspace receptor for advanced glycation end-products (RAGE) and clinical/radiographic outcomes in ARDS patients treated with mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs).
results_summary: The study found that each 10-fold increase in airspace RAGE was independently associated with a 6.6-point increase in day 3 radiographic assessment of lung edema score, indicating a potential role in lung injury severity.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
study_duration: Biomarkers were measured 48 hours after study drug infusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify biomarkers, including soluble Receptor for Advanced Glycation End Products (sRAGE), associated with unfavorable outcomes in COVID-19 patients admitted to general wards or ICUs.
results_summary: Elevated sRAGE levels were associated with unfavorable outcomes in both general ward and ICU COVID-19 patients, suggesting its role in disease progression through pathways like chemotaxis, endothelial dysfunction, and immunothrombosis.
population_specificity: Hospitalized COVID-19 patients (136 in general wards, 119 in ICUs, with 36 overlapping cases).
study_duration: Serial blood sampling during hospitalization (duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) and their receptor (RAGE) in the chronic inflammatory state associated with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: The study found that women with PCOS have elevated levels of AGEs and increased RAGE expression, which contribute to chronic inflammation, endothelial dysfunction, and increased cardiovascular risk. These factors are further aggravated by obesity and hyperinsulinemia.
population_specificity: Reproductive-aged women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between soluble receptor for advanced glycation end products (sRAGE) and COPD, emphysema, and progressive lung function decline, while addressing previous inconsistencies and assay compatibility.
results_summary: Lower blood sRAGE levels were associated with COPD diagnosis, reduced FEV1, and more severe emphysema, though associations with disease progression were inconsistent across cohorts. Genetic variability influenced sRAGE measurements, suggesting genotype should be considered in evaluations.
population_specificity: Participants from four longitudinal cohorts: COPDGene (n=1443), SPIROMICS (n=1623), ECLIPSE (n=2349), and Pittsburgh COPD SCCOR (n=399).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the theoretical role of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) in the development of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that AGEs may play a role in PCOS etiology, but the evidence is theoretical and not substantiated by direct findings in this review. No specific outcomes or effects of AGEs are detailed.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age, particularly those with or at risk for PCOS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of advanced glycation end products (AGEs) and their modulators in diabetes and related complications, as well as the potential of natural products to interact with AGEs for therapeutic benefits.
results_summary: The study found that AGEs and their modulators play a significant role in diabetes progression and complications, and natural products with bioactive constituents can interact with AGEs and related mediators to control and prevent diabetes. The review highlights signaling pathways and phytochemical interactions as potential therapeutic approaches.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on diabetes and related complications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of advanced glycation end products (AGEs) in linking type 2 diabetes (T2D) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) and assess the potential therapeutic effects of anthocyanin in mitigating T2D-mediated AD pathology.
results_summary: The study found that AGEs and their receptor (RAGE) may serve as critical links between T2D and AD by contributing to oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and neuroinflammation. Anthocyanin was shown to enhance insulin sensitivity, reduce inflammation, and potentially counteract amyloid-beta accumulation and neuroinflammatory responses.
population_specificity: Prediabetic (obese) individuals and those with T2D-mediated AD pathology.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role and kinetics of DAMPs and RAGE in acute brain injury and explore clinical strategies for biomarkers and therapeutic interventions.
results_summary: The study found that DAMPs, including S100B, contribute to non-infectious inflammation via RAGE, which may worsen brain injury, but also aid in necrotic cell clearance. Clinical strategies for biomarkers and therapies were discussed.
population_specificity: Patients with acute brain injuries (e.g., traumatic brain injury, subarachnoid hemorrhage, stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationships between Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs), muscle degeneration, and coronary artery calcification in chronic kidney disease patients undergoing peritoneal dialysis.
results_summary: The study found associations between AGEs accumulation and lower muscle stiffness/density, as well as links between muscle degeneration parameters and vascular calcification. Correlations were observed between AGEs levels and muscle elastography, coronary artery calcification, and cumulative glucose load.
population_specificity: 27 patients with chronic kidney disease undergoing peritoneal dialysis (mean age 48±16 years, dialysis vintage 27±17 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify new biomarkers, including sRAGE, for cardiac remodeling in STEMI patients post-revascularization.
results_summary: The study found an inverse association between galectin-3 and sRAGE levels and cardiac remodeling, suggesting potential biomarker utility.
population_specificity: 67 consecutive patients with de novo STEMI who underwent primary angioplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the levels of HMGB1 and sRAGE in different types of pleural effusions and investigate their effects on MeT-5A cell adhesion, migration, and spheroid formation.
results_summary: HMGB1 levels were significantly lower in transudative pleural effusions compared to malignant and parapneumonic ones, while sRAGE levels were higher. High HMGB1 levels correlated with increased cell adherence in all effusion types but had varying effects on migration and spheroid formation depending on the effusion type.
population_specificity: Patients with transudative, malignant, and parapneumonic pleural effusions, with age stratification (above and below 65 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathological implications of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) in aging-related diseases and explore their biological connection to alcohol-mediated tissue injury.
results_summary: The study found that AGEs contribute to oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis, playing a role in aging-related diseases such as diabetes, cardiovascular complications, and neurodegenerative disorders. It also highlighted the connection between AGE-alcohol adducts and alcohol-induced tissue damage.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the role of HMGB1 and its interaction with RAGE and TLRs in the inflammatory processes associated with diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study highlights HMGB1's role in triggering inflammation via RAGE and TLR activation, contributing to diabetic complications, and suggests targeting this pathway as a therapeutic approach.
population_specificity: General discussion on diabetes mellitus, no specific population mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the adverse effects of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) and assess autophagy as a potential therapeutic strategy against AGEs-induced problems.
results_summary: The study highlights that AGEs contribute to diabetes and diabetic complications by disrupting organ function through mechanisms like apoptosis, inflammation, and oxidative stress. It suggests autophagy activation as a promising therapeutic target to mitigate AGEs-related issues.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of AGEs effects, no specific human or animal population mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) in activating neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) and their potential involvement in heart failure pathogenesis.
results_summary: The study suggests that AGEs, through pattern recognition receptors like RAGE, may contribute to NETosis and inflammation in heart failure, but the direct mechanism remains unclear. It also highlights potential therapeutic targets like MPO and PAD4 inhibitors for related conditions.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure and related diseases (e.g., myocardial infarction, atherosclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the role of amines in scavenging toxic aldehydes, including Advanced Glycation End Products, in the brain and propose reevaluating clinically available drugs as potential disease-modifiers for Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found that accumulation of reactive aldehydes, including Advanced Glycation End Products, contributes to neuronal proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, and cell death in Parkinson's disease. It suggests that small molecules like metformin, rasagiline, and hydralazine could be repurposed as disease-modifiers, but improved pharmacology analysis and patient stratification are needed before clinical trials.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of neuroprotective factors in preventing retinal ganglion cell (RGC) injury, including damage caused by advanced glycation end products (AGEs).
results_summary: The abstract highlights that AGEs can trigger RGC death, contributing to neurodegenerative vision loss, but focuses primarily on neuroprotective factors (e.g., CNTF, NGF) that counteract such damage via various signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of neuroprotective mechanisms in RGC injury).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between dietary quality, including advanced glycation end products (AGEs), and the development of World Trade Center obstructive airways disease (WTC-OAD) in the FDNY WTC-HP cohort.
results_summary: The study found that low dietary quality and diets high in AGEs were significantly associated with WTC-OAD, while smoking was not a significant risk factor. The findings suggest that dietary habits, particularly those rich in AGEs, may contribute to pulmonary disease in the context of WTC exposure.
population_specificity: Fire Department of New York (FDNY) WTC-Health Program (WTC-HP) cohort, specifically those with WTC-Lung Injury (WTC-LI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of RAGE axis activation as a mechanistic link between metabolic syndrome components and cancer development.
results_summary: The study suggests that RAGE axis activation contributes to chronic inflammation, creating a microenvironment conducive to tumor growth and progression, potentially linking metabolic syndrome to cancer.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) as biomarkers for disease progression and clinical outcomes, and to present methods for their measurement in skin and plasma.
results_summary: The study found that AGEs are valuable biomarkers for disease prognosis and can be measured effectively using autofluorescence-based methods, which are rapid, cost-effective, and minimally invasive. AGE plasma levels and skin accumulation are temporally related, making them useful predictors of past and present AGE levels in the body.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients and large human populations (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of polyphenolic compounds in inhibiting glycation and Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) formation, as well as their role in managing diabetic complications.
results_summary: The study suggests that polyphenolic compounds may inhibit glycation and AGEs formation through multiple mechanisms, including antioxidant activity, metal chelation, and trapping intermediate dicarbonyl compounds. These compounds may also regulate blood glucose metabolism by enhancing insulin resistance and activating insulin-like growth factor binding protein pathways.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro trials mentioned, in vivo studies in progress).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the significance of Receptor for Advanced Glycation End products (RAGE) as a diagnostic or post-therapeutic prognostic marker for non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLCs).
results_summary: The study found mixed evidence regarding RAGE expression in NSCLCs, with some studies suggesting a protective role (decreased expression) and others implicating RAGE in disease pathogenesis. Genetic polymorphisms of RAGE were associated with NSCLC development and complications, indicating potential diagnostic or prognostic utility.
population_specificity: Patients with non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) in the pathophysiology of diabetic polyneuropathy (DPN) and identify potential therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study highlighted that AGE formation is one of several collateral glucose-utilizing pathways contributing to DPN onset and progression, but no specific efficacy data on AGE inhibition was provided. Current treatments targeting these pathways, like aldose reductase inhibitors, show limited efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic polyneuropathy (DPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the biochemical role of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) in diabetic retinopathy (DR) and explore potential treatment strategies targeting AGE-related pathways.
results_summary: The study highlights that AGEs contribute to oxidative stress and vascular damage in DR, exacerbating retinal complications. Current treatments focus on later stages of DR, but emerging therapies aim to reduce AGE-induced superoxide production and vascular leakage.
population_specificity: Working-age adults with diabetic retinopathy (DR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a low advanced glycation end products (AGE) diet on obesity and related hormones in adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 13 studies showed a significant decrease in BMI (weighted mean difference: -0.3 kg/m²) with a low AGE diet, though results across trials were conflicting.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) in ER stress and chondrocyte death, particularly in the context of osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that AGE accumulation contributes to ER stress in chondrocytes, leading to impaired ECM synthesis and cell death, which is implicated in osteoarthritis pathogenesis. Targeting ER stress or UPR signaling may offer therapeutic potential for osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: Chondrocytes in articular cartilage, particularly in the context of osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanistic link between histone glycation mediated by Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) and cancer epigenetics.
results_summary: The study suggests that glycation-mediated epigenetic modifications, particularly of histones, alter chromatin structure and gene expression, potentially contributing to cancer pathogenesis. It also highlights the possibility of reversing these modifications for therapeutic interventions.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical/epigenetic mechanisms in cancer)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the receptor for advanced glycation end products (RAGE) in the pathological mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2 infection and its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study proposed that RAGE, by binding damage-associated molecular patterns, contributes to tissue damage in SARS-CoV-2 infection, particularly in the lungs, heart, and priming tissues like blood vessels and adipose tissue, suggesting it as a potential therapeutic target.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical focus on SARS-CoV-2 infection mechanisms)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of dietary advanced glycation end products (AGEs) on metabolic syndrome risk factors in adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that a low-AGEs diet significantly reduced insulin resistance, fasting insulin, total cholesterol, and LDL compared to a high-AGEs diet, but showed no effect on other metabolic syndrome components.
population_specificity: Adults, particularly patients with diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of the receptor for advanced glycation end products (RAGE) in melanoma progression and assess its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study highlights that RAGE activation, driven by ligands like S100B and HMGB1, plays a key role in melanoma progression in both cancer and stromal cells. Targeting RAGE could improve outcomes for melanoma patients.
population_specificity: Malignant cutaneous melanoma patients (theoretical focus, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review natural compounds, including those inhibiting Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs), for their antidiabetic potential and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Some natural compounds inhibited AGE formation and showed antidiabetic activity through various mechanisms, including enzyme inhibition and prevention of diabetic complications.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of published studies from 2014-2019).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the role of oxidative stress, including the contribution of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs), in the pathogenesis of diabetic retinopathy and identify potential therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study found that oxidative stress, driven by hyperglycemia-induced metabolic abnormalities including AGE accumulation, contributes to mitochondrial damage, cellular apoptosis, inflammation, and retinal dysfunction in diabetic retinopathy. It also highlighted potential antioxidant therapeutic strategies to mitigate these effects.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with retinopathy (microvascular complication of diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the cellular and molecular mechanisms of AGE-RAGE signaling in AGE-related diseases and explore potential therapeutic strategies involving novel biomolecules and phytochemical compounds.
results_summary: The study found that AGEs contribute to various diseases by inducing inflammation and immunosuppression through RAGE binding, generating proinflammatory cytokines, ROS, and RNI. It highlighted potential therapeutic strategies using Maillard reaction and AGE-RAGE signaling inhibitors, emphasizing the importance of metabolic memory and pharmacogenetics.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article covering broad AGE-related diseases)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of the HMGB1-RAGE axis in neurogenesis post-TBI and its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The HMGB1-RAGE axis mediates neurogenesis, but its effects post-TBI remain unclear. HMGB1 antagonism shows positive results in animal studies, but long-term outcomes and specific effects on neurogenesis are not well-defined.
population_specificity: Animal models and in vitro studies (specific human population not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between tendinopathy and type 2 diabetes (T2D), focusing on the role of metabolic factors like Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) in the degenerative process.
results_summary: The study found that chronic hyperglycemia, AGEs, obesity, and insulin resistance contribute to the development of diabetic tendinopathy, worsening tendon pain, rupture risk, and post-repair outcomes. It highlights the bidirectional impact of tendinopathy and T2D on disease management and quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes and tendinopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between skin autofluorescence (SAF) as a marker of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) and carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) in severely obese patients before and after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: SAF measurements were higher in diabetic obese patients and correlated with BMI, HbA1c, and CIMT. Bariatric surgery improved CIMT but did not reduce SAF measurements in the first year post-surgery.
population_specificity: 432 morbidly obese patients, including diabetic and non-diabetic individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the association of oxidative stress with diabetic parameters (hyperglycemia, glucose variability, and hypoglycemia) and its role in the pathogenesis of diabetic complications, including the creation of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs).
results_summary: The abstract highlights that hyperglycemia promotes AGE formation, leading to excessive ROS production and oxidative stress, which contributes to insulin resistance, impaired insulin secretion, and endothelial dysfunction. It also suggests glucose variability and hypoglycemia may exacerbate diabetic vascular complications through oxidative stress and inflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of diabetic complications and oxidative stress mechanisms).
